title: Scottish judges rule UK parliament suspension ‘unlawful’
text:
Scottish National Party MP Joanna Cherry, who has led the charge against Boris Johnson's suspension of Parliament | Andy Buchanan/AFP/Getty Images Scottish judges rule UK parliament suspension ‘unlawful’ Anti-Brexit parliamentarians hail the ruling as ‘historic.’

LONDON — Three judges at Scotland’s highest civil court have ruled that the British prime minister’s decision to suspend parliament for several weeks was “unlawful,” but the government is refusing to allow MPs back until its appeal of the judgment is heard.

Around 70 parliamentarians had appealed against an earlier ruling by a judge at Scotland's Court of Session that Boris Johnson’s prorogation of parliament between September 9 and October 14 was within the law.

Lord Doherty said at the time that the question of suspension is a political issue and not one to be decided by the courts, while noting that the government has not broken any laws.

In a summary of the appeal judgement, the judges wrote that Johnson's decision to suspend parliament, "was motivated by the improper purpose of stymying Parliament and that it, and what has followed from it, is unlawful."

Scottish National Party MP Joanna Cherry, who spearheaded the case, said on Twitter that today’s ruling is “historic.”

Speaking outside court, Cherry said parliament could be recalled immediately because Scotland’s Court of Session is the highest court in Britain that has ruled on this matter, and because the government lawyers have not yet made an application to suspend the ruling.

A spokesperson for No. 10 Downing Street said the government would appeal to the Supreme Court. “The UK government needs to bring forward a strong domestic legislative agenda. Proroguing parliament is the legal and necessary way of delivering this," the spokesperson said.

In a regular briefing for journalists, the prime minister’s official spokesman insisted that it was “absolutely not” the view of the government that the Scottish court’s decision was politically-motivated adding that the government had “absolute respect for the independence of the judiciary.”

The government would abide by any Supreme Court decision, the spokesman said. If the decision is that a new date for parliament’s return is required, a fresh Privy Council process, whereby ministers advise the Queen on prorogation, would be required.

Independent MP and former attorney general Dominic Grieve said the ruling in Edinburgh is a “serious indictment” on the government and added that parliament should be sitting again within 24 hours.

“I would hope that the government would now realize the extent of the crisis it’s created and recall parliament immediately. It would be much more sensible that the government should simply say we are dropping the Supreme Court case’s appeals on both sides, parliament will sit, and arrange for us to sit within the next 24 hours,” he said.

However, a spokeswoman for the House of Commons speaker’s office said that “any decision to accelerate the meeting of parliament during prorogation is a matter for the government.”

In a separate case arguing the prorogation is unlawful, led by pro-EU campaigner Gina Miller and backed by senior political figures including former Tory Prime Minister John Major, three judges on Wednesday ruled that the prorogation decision was "purely political" and could not be challenged in the courts.

The Supreme Court is due to hear the appeals against both rulings next week.

This story has been updated
description: Anti-Brexit parliamentarians hail the ruling as ‘historic.’
